title: 107_s1414
content: The Act titled "Parent and Teacher Achievement Act of 2001" is cited. It includes provisions for state incentives for teacher testing and merit pay under Title II of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. The Act "Parent and Teacher Achievement Act of 2001" provides state awards for teacher testing, merit-based compensation, and continuing education requirements for teachers. Funding for these awards is 50% of the excess funds appropriated under Title II of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. The Act "Parent and Teacher Achievement Act of 2001" provides state awards for teacher testing, merit-based compensation, and continuing education requirements. States can receive awards under this section based on the total amount available and the number of eligible States. Funds can be used for activities described in section 2207. The term 'State' in this section refers to each of the 50 States and the District of Columbia. The amendments made by subsection (a) will be effective on October 1, 2001. SEC. 3 allows States to use Federal education funds for teacher testing or merit pay programs. SEC. 4 introduces a nonrefundable credit for elementary and secondary school expenses in the Internal Revenue Code. The text introduces a nonrefundable credit for elementary and secondary education expenses in the Internal Revenue Code. The credit allows individuals to claim up to $1000 per qualifying student for qualified expenses incurred during the taxable year. The maximum tuition expenses eligible for the credit are $500 per qualifying student. A qualifying student is defined as a dependent. The text introduces a nonrefundable credit for elementary and secondary education expenses in the Internal Revenue Code. A qualifying student is defined as a dependent or relative enrolled in school on a full-time basis. No double benefit is allowed, and taxpayers can elect to not apply the credit for a taxable year. The text introduces a new credit for contributions to elementary and secondary schools under the Internal Revenue Code, effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 2001. The new tax credit allows individuals and corporations to claim 75% of qualified charitable contributions, with a maximum credit of $500 for individuals ($1,000 for joint returns) and $100,000 for corporations. Qualified charitable contributions are defined as the deductible amount under section 170 for cash donations. The new tax credit allows individuals and corporations to claim 75% of qualified charitable contributions for cash donations to a school tuition organization. The organization must allocate at least 90% of its income to scholarships for elementary and secondary school students eligible for free or reduced-cost lunch. The term 'elementary and secondary school scholarship' refers to scholarships for education up to 12th grade that are excluded from gross income. Special rules include no double benefit deduction and limitations on the credit based on tax calculations. The section discusses the tentative minimum tax for the taxable year and how controlled groups are treated as one taxpayer for tax purposes. Taxpayers can elect to have this section not apply for any taxable year. The section introduces a new credit for elementary and secondary school teachers who provide classroom materials, effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 2001. The new tax credit allows eligible educators to claim up to $1,000 for qualified elementary and secondary education expenses incurred during the taxable year. Eligible educators include teachers, counselors, principals, or aides who work at least 900 hours in a school. Qualified expenses cover books and supplies for instructional purposes. The new tax credit allows eligible educators to claim up to $1,000 for qualified elementary and secondary education expenses, including books, supplies, computer equipment, and supplementary materials used in the classroom. Special rules apply to prevent double benefits and limit the credit based on the regular tax and tentative minimum tax for the year. The new tax credit allows eligible educators to claim up to $1,000 for qualified elementary and secondary education expenses. Special rules apply to prevent double benefits and limit the credit based on the regular tax and tentative minimum tax for the year. Taxpayers may elect to have this section not apply for any taxable year. The amendments made by Sec. 30C provide a tax credit for elementary and secondary school teachers who supply classroom materials. The effective date for these amendments is after December 31, 2001. Additionally, Sec. 7 adjusts the gross income by considering professional development expenses of teachers in these schools. The amendments allow eligible educators to deduct up to $1,500 for professional development expenses related to their teaching subjects. The amendments to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 allow eligible educators to deduct professional development expenses exceeding certain limits for taxable years starting after December 31, 2001.
